mn116:1.2: At one time the Buddha was staying near Rājagaha, on the Isigili Mountain.
mn116:1.3: There the Buddha addressed the mendicants,
mn116:2.1: “Mendicants, do you see that Mount Vebhāra?”
mn116:2.3: “It used to have a different label and description.
mn116:2.4: Do you see that Mount Paṇḍava?”
mn116:2.6: “It too used to have a different label and description.
mn116:2.7: Do you see that Mount Vepulla?”
mn116:2.9: “It too used to have a different label and description.
mn116:2.10: Do you see that Mount Vulture’s Peak?”
mn116:2.12: “It too used to have a different label and description.
mn116:2.13: Do you see that Mount Isigili?”
mn116:3.1: “It used to have exactly the same label and description.
mn116:3.2: Once upon a time, five hundred Buddhas awakened for themselves dwelt for a long time on this Isigili.
mn116:3.3: They were seen entering the mountain, but after entering were seen no more.
mn116:3.4: When people noticed this they said:
mn116:3.6: That’s how it came to be known as Isigili.
mn116:3.7: I shall declare the names of the Buddhas awakened for themselves;
mn116:3.8: I shall extol the names of the Buddhas awakened for themselves;
mn116:3.9: I shall teach the names of the Buddhas awakened for themselves.
mn116:3.10: Listen and pay close attention, I will speak.”
mn116:4.1: “The Buddhas awakened for themselves who dwelt for a long time on this Isigili were named Ariṭṭha,
mn116:5.1: Those saintly beings, untroubled and free of hope,
mn116:5.2: who each achieved awakening by themselves;
mn116:5.4: the supreme persons, free of thorns.
mn116:6.3: awakened for themselves, enders of the attachment to rebirth.
mn116:6.5: Two sages named Jāli, and Aṭṭhaka.
mn116:6.6: Then the Buddha Kosala and Subāhu;
mn116:6.8: right and true, stainless and astute.
mn116:6.9: Kāḷa and Upakāḷa, Vijita and Jita,
mn116:6.10: Aṅga and Paṅga, and Guttijita too;
mn116:6.11: Passin gave up attachment, suffering’s root,
mn116:6.15: Manomaya, and Bandhumant the cutter of conceit,
mn116:6.16: and Tadādhimutta the immaculate and resplendent.
mn116:6.22: another sage, Sayha of peerless effort.
mn116:6.23: There are twelve Ānandas, Nandas, and Upanandas,
mn116:6.24: and Bhāradvāja, bearing his final body.
mn116:6.27: Tissa and Upatissa, who’ve both cut the bonds to rebirth,
mn116:6.28: Upasīdarin and Sīdarin, who’ve both cut off craving.
mn116:6.29: Maṅgala was awakened, free of greed,
mn116:6.30: Usabha cut the net, the root of suffering,
mn116:6.31: Upanīta who attained the state of peace,
mn116:6.35: Mānatthaddha, beautiful and free of greed,
mn116:6.36: and the Buddha Kaṇha, his mind well freed.
mn116:7.1: These and other mighty ones awakened for themselves,
mn116:7.2: enders of the attachment to rebirth—
mn116:7.3: honor these great hermits who are fully extinguished,
